Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Exploring Commercialization of Nanostructured Composite Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is in the technology transfer of novel manufacturing approaches and new nanostructured composite sensors to commercial applications. The manufacturing and sensing approach is scalable for real-world applications and offers potential reliability, flexibility, and cost viability. The industrial scalability of the manufacturing process to produce a wide range of geometries, ranging from complex structural components to miniaturized sensors, may lead to a broad range of potential commercial applications. Nanostructured composite sensors enable distributed sensing with high sensor sensitivity. For possible applications in structural health monitoring the sensors have the potential to dramatically improve the safety and reliability of civil infrastructure or vehicles, resulting in protection against failure and reduced maintenance costs.

This I-Corps project builds upon prior research in both scalable processing of carbon nanotube-based composites and the development of novel sensing methodologies for the detection of deformation and damage in structural materials. The nanotubes are integrated into fiber reinforced composites to create nerve-like electrically conductive networks thereby enabling distributed sensing capabilities arising from resistivity and impedance changes of the network. Through coating carbon nanotubes onto fibers the nanotubes form an electrically conductive sensor network that is sensitive to deformation and damage in structural materials. The techniques offer spatial coverage, distributed sensing capability and manufacturing customizability, and are scalable for field applications with a high degree of flexibility. Complementary analysis techniques are developed to interpret the data collected from the sensors to reconstruct and report the location, extent, and growth of structural damage. Better understanding the critical needs of manufacturers and end-users will enable the team to identify potential future research and commercial applications of these sensors in specific application areas.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF I-Corps project addresses the exploration of transforming the novel sensing technology based on nanostructured composite sensors developed at the University of Delaware into structural health monitoring applications for real-life scenarios including aerospace and infrastructure. The fundamental intellectual merit derives from the cutting-edge research of the team, including scalable processing of carbon nanotube-based composites and the development of new sensing methodologies for the detection of deformation and damage in structural materials. Broader impacts include improved safety and reliability of critical structures and education of the team in entrepreneurship and commercialization of fundamental research.

With the goal of gathering and investigating essential market information to determine the commercial readiness of the proposed work, the team completed ~200 customer face-to-face and phone interviews in North America (US and Canada) and tested 120 hypotheses regarding the business model, value propositions, customer segments, channels, customer relationships, revenue streams and cost structure. The I-Corps training by the team formed the basis for customer discovery. Interviewees participating in the team’s customer interviews included users, influencers, recommenders, decision makers, economic buyers and saboteurs in the ecosystem of structural health monitoring. All of the collected information was further analyzed by the team to understand market opportunities, customer needs and customer pains from the eco system. Conclusions achieved by the team addressed the market need with a large market size in aerospace and infrastructure industries requiring innovative solutions for structural health monitoring.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2017
Modified by: Erik T Thostenson
